author: potuz
content: We should be quite careful about breaking changes on MEV-boost <@388610194608750595> , is it not possible to roll out a version of mev boost that will accept both encodings first, then deprecating the old ones and finally removing support on a major version release? What's the timeline you're thinking on releasing these breaking changes. We had users that only updated prysm for the hard forks and never again

author: potuz
content: So there is no guarantee that if we mark a version as required for validators, it will be adopted

author: sky.cactus
content: Why should we be careful about breaking changes?  What is the bad thing that may happen?

author: potuz
content: every single prysm  validator missing blocks

author: sky.cactus
content: Why would a breaking change in MEV Boost cause prysm to miss blocks?

author: potuz
content: well, it depends on the nature of the breaking change.

author: potuz
content: you are not taking into account that the vast majority of validators are running with MEV-Boost now

author: sky.cactus
content: Seems like worst case likely scenario is just MEV failing to be extracted for a bit (not a problem).

author: potuz
content: it's a single point of failure of the network

author: potuz
content: and it will eventually activate the safety backup

author: sky.cactus
content: If Prysm isn't resilient to MEV Boost outages, fixing that should be the absolute top priority for the Prysm team.

author: potuz
content: Well, if you fail only after sending the signed blinded block, there's nothing you can do about it

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, there is one failure mode that Prysm cannot be resilient to.  That is a relay thing though, not an MEV Boost thing.

author: sky.cactus
content: I suppose you could sign something and send to MEV Boost and then MEV Boost fails to forward to the relay.

author: sky.cactus
content: But this argument seems to just be "don't ever change anything, because the system is brittle".

author: potuz
content: if the relayer is out, the network will notice it and we will just stop using it. But a problem with mev-boost that leads to failures only after sending signed blocks is irrecoverable

author: potuz
content: No, my argument is "if you have a public facing API and you want to make changes, then follow the standard procedure of deprecating first, making it public, make sure that all consumers have time to adopt the new version, and only break on major releases"

author: potuz
content: this applies to any API, not only MEV-boost

author: sky.cactus
content: I would agree if I felt that an MEV outage was a bad thing.

author: sky.cactus
content: In reality, an MEV outage is a good thing with the exception of one very specific failure scenario.

author: sky.cactus
content: So I think we should be very careful to ensure that one failure mode cannot occur, and basically YOLO with everything else (almost hoping for outages other than that one scenario).

author: sky.cactus
content: In an ideal world, MEV Boost would be offline/broken as much as possible (save the one bad scenario) but not quite enough for people to engineer an alternative.

author: sky.cactus
content: I feel like 1 nine is sufficient to achieve that goal.

author: ajsutton
content: From the conversation above this api change would break it in exactly the case that’s unrecoverable. I’m not sure that’s a guarantee but it was explicitly mentioned as a possibility of the change.
